justification: Norwegian law provides financial support for families: the universal child benefit (barnetrygd) for children under 18 and the cash‑for‑care benefit (kontantstøtte) for children aged about 13–19 months (with rules for part‑time kindergarten and residency/membership requirements). These are set out on NAV’s official pages for Child benefit and Cash‑for‑care benefit. ([nav.no](https://www.nav.no/barnetrygd/en))

justification: The Skatteetaten guidance confirms parents can claim foreldrefradrag for documented childcare/pass expenses for children who at the end of the income year are 11 years or younger; children aged 12 or older only qualify if they have special needs requiring care. The Skatteetaten pages also state the documentation and payment rules and the maximum amounts. ([skatteetaten.no](https://www.skatteetaten.no/person/skatt/hjelp-til-riktig-skatt/familie-og-helse/barn/foreldrefradrag/?utm_source=openai))

justification: The cited Norwegian Tax Administration pages state that family day-care centres and childminders are subject to specific tax rules and that parents can claim expense allowances/deductions for childcare costs; these pages support the AI's summary that Norwegian law provides tax deductions/exemptions for private family day-care/childminders and allows deduction/expense allowance for childcare reported by centres. The sources cited are authoritative (Norwegian Tax Administration).

justification: The answer correctly states the statutory basic staffing requirement in Norway: §19 of the Kindergarten Act (barnehageloven) requires at least one staff member per three children under age three (0–2), with municipal dispensations possible. This is reflected in the Lovdata text of the Act and summarized by the Utdanningsdirektoratet guidance and fact pages on bemanningsnorm. ([lovdata.no](https://lovdata.no/dokument/NLE/lov/2005-06-17-64/KAPITTEL_1%23KAPITTEL_1?utm_source=openai))

The AI statement matches Norwegian statutory rules and official guidance: Altinn (official Norwegian government guidance) states maternity leave for the mother is the last three weeks before birth and the first six weeks after birth (total 9 weeks/63 days) and cites the Working Environment Act and National Insurance Act. The Working Environment Act §12-4 requires six weeks post‑natal leave for the mother and §12-2/§12-5 and related National Insurance Act provisions support the prenatal three‑week requirement and parental benefit structure. ([info.altinn.no](https://info.altinn.no/en/start-and-run-business/working-conditions/print-leave-of-absence-and-holidays/paid-and-unpaid-leave/))

justification: Lovdata §14-12 states the father's reserved quota is 75 stønadsdager (15 uker) when parents choose full (100%) coverage. The AI converted 15 weeks to 105 calendar days (15×7) which is misleading because the statute and benefit rules refer to 'stønadsdager' (benefit days) — Lovdata explicitly: "75 stønadsdager (15 uker) ... er forbeholdt faren (fedrekvote)". NAV/SNL descriptions also state the fedrekvote is 15 weeks (75 stønadsdager). ([lovdata.no](https://lovdata.no/lov/1997-02-28-19/%C2%A714-12?utm_source=openai))
corrected_answer: Fedrekvote (father's quota) is 75 stønadsdager, i.e. 15 uker, when parents choose full (100%) coverage. The relevant legal formulation uses 'stønadsdager' (benefit days) and states 75 stønadsdager (15 uker); do not convert this to 105 calendar days without clarifying that the law counts benefit days. ([lovdata.no](https://lovdata.no/lov/1997-02-28-19/%C2%A714-12?utm_source=openai))
replacement_citations: [{"title": "Folketrygdloven §14-12 — Lovdata", "url": "https://lovdata.no/lov/1997-02-28-19/%C2%A714-12"}, {"title": "fedrekvote – Store norske leksikon (snl.no)", "url": "https://snl.no/fedrekvote"}]

justification: The AI correctly stated the fedrekvote is 15 weeks at 100% and 19 weeks at 80%, but misreported the conversion to days for the 80% option (stated 19 weeks = 95 days). Authoritative Norwegian sources show: fedrekvote = 15 uker (100%) and 19 uker (80%). When expressed as calendar days 15 weeks = 105 days and 19 weeks = 133 days; when expressed as paid benefit days (stønadsdager) 15 weeks = 75 stønadsdager and 19 weeks = 95 stønadsdager. See Store norske leksikon and Norway.no (Norge.no). ([snl.no](https://snl.no/fedrekvote?utm_source=openai))
corrected_answer: Corrected statement: The fedrekvote (father's quota) in Norway is 15 weeks when parents choose 100% compensation, and 19 weeks when they choose the 80% (reduced) compensation. In calendar days this is 15 weeks = 105 calendar days and 19 weeks = 133 calendar days. In terms of paid benefit days (stønadsdager) used in Norwegian parental benefit rules, 15 weeks corresponds to 75 stønadsdager and 19 weeks corresponds to 95 stønadsdager. (Sources: Store norske leksikon; Norge.no / NAV guidance.)

justification: The AI's answer correctly identifies the statutory protection in the Norwegian Working Environment Act (Section 15-9) which prohibits dismissal due to pregnancy and protects employees during pregnancy and for specified post-birth/adoption periods; authoritative sources (Lovdata and the Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority) confirm this prohibition and describe the narrow exceptions and burden on the employer to show other lawful grounds. citeturn0search1turn0search0

justification: Norway's Equality and Anti-Discrimination Act (likestillings- og diskrimineringsloven) §34 imposes an obligation on employers to ensure equal pay for the same work or work of equal value and identifies objective criteria (such as competence, responsibility, effort and working conditions) for assessing equal value. The cited Lovdata text §34 and the NHO/Arbinn guidance set out this legal basis and practical pay-mapping guidance supporting the AI's answer.

justification: Norwegian law does not allow a general, gender-based ban on women working night shifts. The Working Environment Act (Arbeidsmiljøloven) prohibits discrimination and regulates working hours and night work through health/safety rules and special protections (e.g., for pregnant workers and young workers). The Labour Inspection Authority guidance on night work confirms rules focus on working-time safety rather than blanket gender bans. (See Arbeidsmiljøloven and Arbeidstilsynet: Night work).
replacement_citations: [{"title": "Working Environment Act (Arbeidsmiljøloven) — Lovdata", "url": "https://lovdata.no/dokument/NL/lov/2005-06-17-62"}, {"title": "Night work — Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority (Arbeidstilsynet)", "url": "https://www.arbeidstilsynet.no/en/working-conditions/work-time/night-work/"}]

justification: Norwegian law broadly prohibits sex/gender discrimination (Equality and Anti-Discrimination Act) and guarantees equal access to employment; the Working Environment Act imposes workplace safety duties rather than categorical bans on women in dangerous jobs, while providing specific protections for pregnant and breastfeeding workers and other vulnerable groups. The cited sources (Working Environment Act guidance from the Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority and the Equality and Anti-Discrimination Act on Lovdata) support these points.

Norwegian Equality and Anti-Discrimination Act prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex (see Equality and Anti-Discrimination Act §6) and thereby bars public authorities from imposing lawful restrictions that treat women differently in employment or sector access; the Constitution further supports equal treatment obligations. The AI answer ('No') correctly applies these provisions to reject lawful sex-based exclusion from economic sectors. Sources cited (Lovdata for the Act and the Constitution) support this conclusion.

justification: Norway's traditional guarantee (minstepensjon/garantipensjon) and the historic normal retirement age for alderspensjon has been 67 years. Reforms introduced after 2011 made retirement flexible (allowing pension take-up from age 62) and introduced a life-expectancy-linked normative pension age for younger cohorts — but the guarantee pension remains payable from age 67. This is consistent with NAV guidance and the Norwegian government explanation of pension reforms. (See NAV overview and regjeringen.no reform page cited by the AI answer.)
replacement_citations: [{"title": "Alderspensjon – NAV (overview)", "url": "https://www.nav.no/satser/nn"}, {"title": "Et mer sosialt og rettferdig pensjonssystem – regjeringen.no", "url": "https://www.regjeringen.no/no/aktuelt/et-mer-sosialt-og-rettferdig-pensjonssystem/id3018933/"}]

justification: The AI answer states Norway's statutory/ordinary pensionable age is 67. That was true under the older rules, but Norway completed further pension reforms in 2024–2025 that replace the fixed age of 67 for younger cohorts with a life‑expectancy‑linked 'standard retirement age' and gradual increases for people born in/after 1963/1964. Authoritative summaries (SSA International Update Nov 2024) and recent Norwegian/industry guidance (Tekna) describe the new life‑expectancy adjustments and that flexible drawing from age 62 remains possible. The AI answer omits these legal changes and so is out of date. ([ssa.gov](https://www.ssa.gov/policy/docs/progdesc/intl_update/2024-11/index.html?utm_source=openai))
corrected_answer: As of the pre‑reform rules the standard full old‑age pension age in Norway was 67 and early, flexible drawing was possible from age 62 with actuarial reductions. However, following pension reform passed in 2024 and implemented from 2025 onwards for younger cohorts, Norway replaced the fixed age 67 for many birth cohorts with a life‑expectancy‑linked 'standard retirement age' that will gradually increase for people born in/after 1963/1964. Flexible withdrawal between ages 62 and 75 remains available, subject to actuarial adjustments and the specific cohort rules.
replacement_citations: [{"title": "International Update, November 2024 — Social Security Administration", "url": "https://www.ssa.gov/policy/docs/progdesc/intl_update/2024-11/index.html"}, {"title": "Pension in Norway — Tekna (overview of new rules and cohort changes)", "url": "https://www.tekna.no/en/salary-and-negotiations/pension/"}]

justification: The AI answer correctly identifies § 15-13a of the Working Environment Act (Arbeidsmiljøloven) as the statutory provision establishing an age‑based termination right and correctly states the general age limit is 72 years. However the answer omits recent legislative changes (2025) that remove the employer’s ability to set company‑specific lower age limits and harmonise the public‑sector age limit to 72 from 1 January 2026. The sources cited by the AI (Lovdata §15‑13a and the Act) support the 72‑year limit, but do not reflect the 2025 amendment and transition rules that affect company‑specific limits and state sector rules. See recent government/sector guidance and legal practice updates noting the change effective 1 Jan 2026. ([spk.no](https://www.spk.no/en/news/2025/more-people-will-be-able-to-work-until-the-age-of-72/?utm_source=openai))
corrected_answer: Legal basis: Working Environment Act (Arbeidsmiljøloven) § 15‑13a permits termination of employment due to age when an employee reaches 72 years — this is the statutory general upper age limit. Recent amendments adopted in 2025 remove the employer’s general power to maintain company‑specific lower age limits (previously often 70) and raise/harmonise the public‑sector age limit to 72; these changes take effect 1 January 2026. Exceptions remain for occupations where a lower age limit is objectively necessary for health or public safety.
replacement_citations: [{"title": "Arbeidsmiljøloven § 15-13 a — Opphør av arbeidsforhold grunnet alder (Lovdata)", "url": "https://lovdata.no/nav/lov/2005-06-17-62/%C2%A715-13a"}, {"title": "More people will be able to work until the age of 72 - Statens pensjonskasse (news)", "url": "https://www.spk.no/en/news/2025/more-people-will-be-able-to-work-until-the-age-of-72/"}]

justification: The AI's answer correctly cites the Working Environment Act (Section 15-13 a) stating employment may be terminated at age 72 and that a company-specific lower limit down to 70 has been permitted under conditions. Lovdata shows §15-13a(1)-(3) allowing termination at 72 and permitting a lower company-specific limit not below 70 under set conditions. ([lovdata.no](https://lovdata.no/dokument/NLE/lov/2005-06-17-62/%2A?utm_source=openai)) However, the AI omitted recent legislative changes: the Norwegian government has adopted amendments removing the option for employers to set an internal company age limit of 70, with the change to take effect 1 January 2026 (reported by legal commentators and firms). This makes the AI's description incomplete/outdated. ([knowledge.dlapiper.com](https://knowledge.dlapiper.com/dlapiperknowledge/globalemploymentlatestdevelopments/2025/Proposed-changes-to-the-Norwegian-Working-Environment-Act?utm_source=openai))
corrected_answer: Current law (text of §15-13a): employment may be terminated when an employee reaches age 72. The statute also (currently) allows a lower age limit where necessary for health or safety, and contains a provision (§15-13a(3)) that has until recently permitted a company-specific lower limit down to 70 if strict conditions are met (made known to employees, applied consistently, satisfactory pension scheme, discussion with employee representatives). However, the Norwegian government has adopted amendments that will abolish the company-specific 70-year exception so that, from 1 January 2026, the general age limit of 72 will be the standard in most workplaces; only health-and-safety-based lower limits will remain possible. Practitioners should rely on the current statutory text for matters before 1 January 2026 and on the amended regime for cases on or after 1 January 2026, and verify implementation and any transitional rules in the final enacted statute and secondary guidance.
replacement_citations: [{"title": "Act relating to the working environment (Working Environment Act) — Lovdata — Section 15-13 a", "url": "https://lovdata.no/dokument/NLE/lov/2005-06-17-62/%2A"}, {"title": "Changes to the Norwegian Working Environment Act (update) — DLA Piper (summary of adopted amendments, including removal of company-specific 70) ", "url": "https://knowledge.dlapiper.com/dlapiperknowledge/globalemploymentlatestdevelopments/2025/Proposed-changes-to-the-Norwegian-Working-Environment-Act"}]

justification: Norwegian National Insurance (NAV) provides pension accrual for periods of care work: care periods for young children are credited as pensionable income (calculated using the National Insurance basic amount, G) and are automatically registered when the parent receives child benefit for children under six. This is described on NAV's guidance pages about accumulation of pension rights for care work and child benefit. (See NAV: "Accumulation of pension rights for care work" and "Child benefit (barnetrygd)").

justification: Norwegian Gender Equality Act imposes affirmative obligations on public authorities to carry out active, targeted equality work (see Gender Equality Act §12 summary). Norwegian procurement guidance permits and encourages inclusion of human-rights and social criteria (including gender-responsive requirements) in public procurement where they are relevant and proportionate. The cited regjeringen.no summary and anskaffelser.no guidance support the AI's conclusion.

justification: Authoritative sources confirm that 'sivilstand' (marital/civil status) is not a separate protected ground in Norwegian anti-discrimination law and thus there is no explicit blanket prohibition on recruitment discrimination solely based on marital status; NOU 2009:14 discusses that sivilstand is not an independent discrimination ground and that treatment on that basis can sometimes be assessed under other grounds (e.g. sex). Separate rules prohibit asking about pregnancy/family planning in recruitment — as set out by the Likestillings- og diskrimineringsombudet (LDO). ([regjeringen.no](https://www.regjeringen.no/no/dokumenter/nou-2009-14/id566624/?ch=3&utm_source=openai))

justification: The Working Environment Act (Chapter 13) explicitly prohibits direct and indirect discrimination on the basis of age (Section 13-1) and states that the provisions apply to all aspects of employment including advertising, appointment/selection, pay and working conditions and termination (Section 13-2). This supports the AI answer that age discrimination is prohibited in recruitment and all aspects of employment. Sources: Lovdata (Working Environment Act §§13-1, 13-2, 13-3) and the Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority summary. ([lovdata.no](https://lovdata.no/dokument/NLE/lov/2005-06-17-62/%2A?utm_source=openai))

justification: Arbeidsmiljøloven § 10-2(3) explicitly states that "Arbeidstaker har rett til fleksibel arbeidstid dersom dette kan gjennomføres uten vesentlig ulempe for virksomheten," which matches the AI answer. Authoritative sources (Lovdata and the Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority) confirm this interpretation and explain that the right is conditional on it not causing substantial/"vesentlig" inconvenience to the employer. justification: The AI answer accurately states that Norwegian law does not grant employees a unilateral statutory right to permanent remote work; arrangements for home office require employer-employee agreement and are governed by regulations on workplace/home office conditions. This is supported by the Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority guidance on home office obligations and Altinn's employer guidance on home office arrangements. (Arbeidstilsynet: 'Hjemmekontor' and Altinn: 'Hjemmekontor - hva må du som arbeidsgiver tenke på?').

justification: The AI answer correctly states that Norway publishes public data on barnehager. Statistics Norway (SSB) maintains and publishes statistics and datasets on kindergartens (barnehager), including numbers by municipality and ownership, and the Directorate for Education (Utdanningsdirektoratet) provides official guidance and registries for private and public barnehager. These two sources support the claim that such public data is available. (Sources cited: SSB and Utdanningsdirektoratet).

The cited Statistics Norway (SSB) StatBank table 14320 provides time-use data disaggregated by sex and age; the SSB survey page on unpaid welfare work (Survey on living conditions) documents collection of unpaid care/unpaid welfare work statistics. Both sources indicate anonymized public dissemination of sex-disaggregated statistics by SSB. citeturn0search0turn0search1

justification: Norway's Equality and Anti-Discrimination Act establishes the Equality and Anti-Discrimination Ombud (Likestillings- og diskrimineringsombudet) and the Anti-Discrimination Tribunal (Diskrimineringsnemnda) and provides complaint, investigation, remedial-order and compensation mechanisms; government guidance confirms these enforcement bodies and their role in promoting equal pay. The cited Lovdata Chapter 6 sets out the Ombud/Tribunal functions and remedies, and the regjeringen.no page explains Norway's framework for gender-equality enforcement. citeturn0search0turn0search1
